Award.AwardTitle: RECON - Occultations of Outer Solar System Objects
Award.AbstractNarration: This pilot project will initiate the development of a large, coordinated citizen-science network to study small Solar System bodies in the Kuiper Belt. Studies of this population of objects have already led to major improvements in the understanding of planet formation and Solar System history; determining their sizes is essential to constraining their surface albedos and estimating the size-frequency distributions of different dynamical sub-populations. The Research and Education Cooperative Occultation Network (RECON) is proposed to eventually be a collection of 40 citizen-scientist-operated stations spread across the western United States from southern Arizona to northern Washington, each employing an 11-inch telescope and video camera system, with the purpose of measuring sizes of objects in the outer Solar System as small as 100 km by observing occultations of background stars. The full network is expected eventually to produce measurements of the sizes of 1 to 2 Kuiper Belt objects per year. This pilot project will support the initial establishment of 10 stations in order to develop and refine operating procedures and demonstrate the scientific capabilities of the network. The observing equipment will be located primarily in underserved communities, and affiliated with educational institutions such as K-12 school districts, libraries, and informal science centers. Local participants will be recruited and educated to carry out observations at their local sites, thus not only participating in cutting-edge research as citizen scientists, but also helping to disseminate the results through the network and in their own communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
RECON - the Research and Education Collaborative Occultation Network - is an innovative citizen science astronomy research effort that is involving rural communities across the western United States in an investigation of minor planets out beyond the orbit of Neptune. The project is measuring the sizes and other characteristics of known trans-Neptunian objects (TNOs) through stellar occultations which occur when a planetary object passes in front of a distant star. Results from this project will place important constraints on models for the size distribution, formation, and evolution of the early Solar System.

While over 1,500 TNOs have been discovered in the past two decades, substantial uncertainties exist in our knowledge of their orbital positions because we have monitored them for only small fractions of their orbits around the Sun. These positional uncertainties lead to challenges in knowing exactly where telescopes need to be placed to observe a given TNO occultation event. RECON addresses this challenge by establishing a network of over 50 telescopes across the western United States.

NSF Award 1212159 provided funding to pilot the development of the RECON network. Through the project, RECON established a pilot network of 14 telescope sites located between Tulelake, California and Tonopah, Nevada (see attached map). Students, teachers, and amateur astronomers from each of these communities constitute RECON teams committed to participating in 6-8 occultation events per year. Participants were recruited during Fall 2012, supplied with telescope and camera equipment during Winter 2013, and trained through a four-day workshop held in Carson City, Nevada in Spring 2013. Between May 2013 to May 2015, RECON coordinated 11 official occultation campaigns (nine involving main belt asteroids and two involving TNOs) and several optional campaigns to test the perfomance of the pilot network. Building upon this pilot effort, RECON was extended during the 2014-15 academic year to involve telescope sites from the Canadian border to our border with Mexico through support from NSF award (1413072).

RECON is involving K-12 students, teachers, and community members from rural towns across the western US in an authentic citizen science research investigation. In addition to participating in coordinated occultation campaigns that will lead to published research, each community benefits through receiving telescope/camera resources and training that can be used for numerous educational projects. The project has also resulted in enhanced networking both within and between RECON communities, with several examples of amateur astronomers becoming more involved in K-12 classrooms and teachers sharing educational resources and ideas across communities. The pilot RECON project played a critical role in demonstrating the successful recruitment, training, and maintanence of a dynamic and effective telescope network capable of measuring occultations of TNOs.

More information about RECON is available at http://www.tnorecon.net
